picks.title: Ben Youssef Medersa
picks.whyWeLoveIt: Once the largest Islamic college in Morocco, this 14th-century masterpiece features stunning zellige tilework, carved stucco, and cedar wood carvings. The central courtyard with its reflecting pool is pure architectural poetry.

picks.title: Koutoubia Mosque
picks.whyWeLoveIt: The iconic 12th-century minaret dominates Marrakech's skyline and inspired the Giralda in Seville. While non-Muslims can't enter, the surrounding gardens are perfect for a sunset stroll with views of the Atlas Mountains.

picks.title: Badi Palace
picks.whyWeLoveIt: The atmospheric ruins of Sultan Ahmad al-Mansur's 16th-century palace, once called 'The Incomparable'. Storks nest in the crumbling walls, and the vast sunken gardens hint at past grandeur. The underground prison is hauntingly atmospheric.

picks.title: Almoravid Koubba
picks.whyWeLoveIt: The only surviving structure from the Almoravid dynasty (12th century), this small ablutions pavilion is a treasure of early Moroccan architecture. The intricate carved dome and arches showcase the origins of Marrakech's architectural legacy.

picks.title: Saadian Tombs
picks.whyWeLoveIt: Sealed for centuries and rediscovered in 1917, these ornate 16th-century royal tombs feature Italian Carrara marble, gilded honeycomb ceilings, and exquisite zellige. The Hall of Twelve Columns is breathtakingly beautiful.

picks.title: Bahia Palace
picks.whyWeLoveIt: A breathtaking testament to Moroccan craftsmanship — intricate zellige tile work, carved cedar ceilings, and tranquil courtyards create an atmosphere of timeless beauty. Don't miss the harem quarters with painted wooden ceilings.

picks.title: Centre de la Femme Artisane
picks.whyWeLoveIt: A women's cooperative showcasing authentic Moroccan handicrafts at fixed prices. Support local artisans directly while finding beautiful carpets, embroidery, leather goods, and textiles — all made by skilled Moroccan women.

picks.title: Mustapha Blaoui
picks.whyWeLoveIt: A legendary warehouse packed floor-to-ceiling with Moroccan treasures — lanterns, furniture, ceramics, textiles, and antiques. Interior designers fly in from around the world to source here. Overwhelming in the best way.

picks.title: Les Nomades de Marrakech
picks.whyWeLoveIt: A beautifully curated boutique in the medina specializing in Berber carpets, vintage textiles, and nomadic tribal art. Each piece has a story, and the knowledgeable staff share the cultural heritage behind every item.

picks.title: Jardin Majorelle Boutique
picks.whyWeLoveIt: The garden's boutique offers exquisite YSL-inspired designs, Majorelle blue ceramics, and curated Moroccan crafts. While pricier than the souks, the quality and design are impeccable — perfect for special gifts.

picks.title: Naturom
picks.whyWeLoveIt: Morocco's answer to organic beauty — argan oil, black soap, ghassoul clay, and rose water straight from local cooperatives. Learn about traditional beauty rituals and take home authentic hammam products.

picks.title: Rahba Kedima
picks.whyWeLoveIt: The 'Old Square' is Marrakech's most atmospheric marketplace — apothecary stalls selling spices, dried herbs, traditional remedies, and yes, chameleons. The surrounding carpet dealers and basket weavers add to the sensory overload.
